data.text: Carrying Water on the Bicycle in Summer when It's VERY HOT AND SUNNY?

Hey y'all! I hope you are doing great! Just a quick question: **HOW DO YOU CARRY WATER, WHILE TOURING, IN THE SUMMER WHEN IT'S VERY HOT AND SUNNY? **Do you just carry your water in regular water bottles and let it become lava, or do you have a solution to maintain your water fresh? The best solution I've thought of is getting some cargo cages like the ***Blackburn outpost cargo cages*** and strapping whatever insulated bottle you want that fits your frame. The problem is that the Blackburn cargo cages are unavailable at the moment in most sites and I don't have time to wait for them to arrive. Another solution is using ***insulated bike water bottles***. I even had bought the *ELITE Iceberg insulated cycling water bottle 650ml** ***from *Decathlon *to try insulated bike water bottles, but I've found that they are not effective. In fact, they are a little heavier, have a lower volume capacity and don't keep your water fresh after 45 minutes. To the point where I don't really see the value in getting the insulated and not the regular ones. Unfortunately, I want to carry as much water as possible, but due to the frame bag I don't have much space left for bottles. So what are your thoughts on the matter? How do you deal with the situation? I'm looking forward to your answers! Thanks a lot in advance! Have great rides!
backpack type hydration system/ handlebar bottle bags/ lower frame triangle water system
data.author: Edvarts Daniels Emersons

data.text: fill a couple of water bottles 1/4 to 1/3 full and freeze them. when you set out for your ride, fill up with cool water and let the melt keep things refreshing. works for a while anyway.
data.author: Mike Bauer

data.text: Hello ! Thanks for the reply! That's an old-school trick that never fails! Unfortunately, while touring I won't be able to freeze my bottles beforehands... Good idea though!
data.author: Evangelos Silva Angelopoulos

data.text: SIGG bottles in Topeak Versacages, Nalgene 1.5 ltr with neoprene sleeve. When pausing at a creek, lay the bottles in the water.
data.author: Axel Knobbe

data.text: When I'm on a long tour and heading into the heat I have a 10l Ortlieb water bladder which I wrap one of those space survival blankets around. Then attach it to the back of my rear rack with the spout showing. Keeps my water from the night before drinkable till about 4pm the next day then repeat over night.
data.author: Barry Warner

data.text: I tried a camel pack but found the water got warm and tasted of plastic. I have tried insulated bottles but it reduces the amount you can carry. The best option I have found is to take a few minutes to find new water sources as you go along. Keep one bottle on the bike and a second in a bag if you can.
data.author: Steve Lindley

data.text: so renewing the water, hum? Yeap, that's a good idea whenever possible. Thank you very much!
data.author: Evangelos Silva Angelopoulos

data.text: On long hot days, I am grateful for any water at all. Lukewarm plastic-y water can be a life changingly delicious delight. Such are the lessons that touring teaches you.
data.author: Babs Lev

data.text: Backpack with a 1.5l hydro pack. Works even better if you can freeze it the night before.
data.author: Jimmy Koyote

data.text: I just stop to refill more often.
data.author: Brad Kay

data.text: My solution is cold beer at the local shops or fresh drafted beer at the pubs! Or fresh water from the taps whenever I find them along the road! When it's hot like today any kind of bottle will heat up the water inside. Only few ice rocks could hold the low temperature for a while!
data.author: Milan Boric

data.text: I just drink it hot. Biking in Cairo, the water would get hot quickly, and never figured out anything better than freezing a bottle the night before.
data.author: Monica Luisa Barreto

data.text: Same racks. 2L pop bottles. Problem solved!
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: Carry a life straw ðŸ˜Š
data.author: Abhishek  Roychowdhury

data.text: do you use one? I thought of getting the sawyer mini as the life straw can't fill my bottles, but can only be used as a straw. If you use one, how do you deal with the problem that you can't fill bottles with it?
data.author: Evangelos Silva Angelopoulos

data.text: you can fill a bottle up and use the straw on the bottle itself
data.author: Pedro Claro

data.text: I carry a sawyer mini and absolutely love it.
data.author: Danny Wade

data.text: Do you freeze the insulated bottles before using them? Mine have a gel that if frozen, keeps everything colder.
data.author: Bettegail Shively

data.text: Hello . Thanks for the reply. I'm sure freezing them beforehands is effective (especially if you are using gel insulated bottles), but mine are not gel insulated and while touring freezing my bottles won't really be an option...
data.author: Evangelos Silva Angelopoulos

data.text: Take some tea bags with you, so when the water is warm, you can make tea.ðŸ™ƒ
data.author: Toon Hurkmans

data.text: very creative! Thank you!
data.author: Evangelos Silva Angelopoulos

data.text: , de nada.
data.author: Toon Hurkmans

data.text: I have several places: a water backpack which I drink first, then two bottles strapped below the aerobars, and one bottle on the rear of my trunk. Mainly because I don't like stopping and refilling that much. But usually, I never use up all of it
data.author: Sandra Peters

data.text: Better that than cold water. That stuff can give wicked stomach cramps.
data.author: Monika Cognomen

data.text: ÃŽve got two plastic bags from platypus. Great to have them. They weigh almost nothing when empty however when filledâ€¦.
data.author: Sarah Delafortrie

data.text: Met a guy touring who puts old socks around the bottles and soaks them with water... Apparently works quite well (probably not for hours and hours in high temps etc!)
data.author: Jonathan Dean

data.text: that's due to evaporative cooling from the socks. another old-school method. that's why old canteens had fabric panels on them.
data.author: Mike Bauer

data.text: In the summer I use my water bag for drinking and the bottles for washing and cooking, I fill my water bag with cold water and put it in Plastic bag and Then wrap it tightly with a long cloth And put it under my gear out of the sun or in backpack, This way, the bag keeps cool for 6 hours in the North African summer.
data.author: ØºÙˆÙŠÙ„Ø¨ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø±Ø¶Ø§

data.text: Look for a map of public fountains along your path and refill as you go, I don't know if it's true out of Italy but cemeteries usually have one
data.author: Lo La Pesi

data.text: Portugal too. Most villages have multiple fountains with potable water. Mountainous regions always have safe creeks to drink from. Water tablets are useful in tight situations. A stainless steel Jerry can is expensive but ultimately the best tool out there for the job. The bigger the volume of water the longer it takes to warm up. Having a reflective coating helps
data.author: Pedro Claro

data.text: We make a "bag" from an old white t-shirt to put the bottle in. This way it is a bit protected from the sun and doesn't heat up so quickly. Also what others have said - freeze it during the night if you have a chance.
data.author: Ivana Å enk

data.text: Wet the t-shirt before wrapping and by the evaporating water your content cools down
data.author: Albert Dijkshoorn

data.text: I fill my camelback with ice, which feels great. Drink my insulated water bottles first. Once theyâ€™re empty, the ice in the camelback has melted down to drink.
data.author: Sarah Slowik

data.text: Try these stainless steel water bottles from Under Armour. Theyâ€™re insulated and they keep ice water cold especially when the bottle is in direct sunlight. Many times Iâ€™ve done a ride with a group and Iâ€™ve left this bottle filled with ice cubes and water in my car in the sunlight. After getting back to my car from a 2 or 3 hour ride, the outside of the bottle feels warm but the water inside is frigid cold. Direct sunlight seems to do this with these bottles, Iâ€™m not sure how but it works. I think the model is called Beyond.
data.author: Ian Whiting

data.text: yeah i use a 750ml chilly's thermal bottle as the last drank, a cage bottle which goes first and a water bladder which i stuff in the middle of my sleeping bag ( great insulation)
data.author: Pedro Claro

data.text: Beautiful pictures. Good luck on you. Be safe!
data.author: Mikael Ljungberg

data.text: CamelBak 3L hydration pack.
data.author: Eric Knudstrup

data.text: If you want to keep it in bottle and on the frame then something vacuum sealed such as snow monkey, which will keep it cold for approx 12 hours. If you have a frame bag then watter bladder is the way to go
data.author: Rok Pajer

data.text: I have 5 bottle cages, 3 (for water) on the frame and 2(electrolyte mix) behind the seat. I quit trying to freeze water, it's just warm after a few hours anyway.
data.author: Sarah Mullett

data.text: Blackburn outposts are good and in stock at amazon
data.author: Jake Klamerus

data.text: Stop at the next hardware store and buy an inexpensive universal faucet key. A 4-way key. There's water everywhere that way. Never has been a problem.
data.author: Bill Bacon

data.text: I think that depends on the country and area, where you are cykling. I doubt I will find that on the Sinai peninsula.
data.author: Dorothee Hildebrandt

data.text: would prefer to have a thermos .
data.author: Adane Tarik

data.text: It is still fresh water even though warmed up by the sun. Get used to just drinking it as it is. It is a waste of time trying to keep it cool. And for the US people: stop using ice, then the difference is smaller...
data.author: Martin Koole

data.text: I keep a stash in the bags among clothes. Warm water is just as moisturizing as cold water. This is mental
data.author: Michel Campeau

data.text: I wear a 70 oz. (2L) CamelBak insulated hydration pack, and fill it as full of ice as possible, then add cold water (ice water preferably) to completely fill it. Keeps the water icy cold, and helps keep my back cool too. If I stop somewhere for lunch and ice is available, I top it off with as much ice as will fit in it.
data.author: Robert J. Shanks

data.text: When we were biking in hot Sudan, warm water did taste fine, cold water not! Including soup coffee we drank about 8 liters a day
data.author: Jw Sandker

data.text:
Here is what I am using and have loved it. It took a few steps to get it to fit as you can see here I had to use some extensions. But its been perfect anf hot days I put a sock over the bottles to keep them a bit cooler. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vgYXoM84H04&t=1s
World Tour Bike Build - Tour Garage
youtube.com
data.author: McKenley Newman

data.text: The simplest solution ever - take an old sock, soak it in water and pull it over the bottle. As long as the sock stays wet, water inside the bottle will be cold. Thick white socks stay wet the longest (white color doesn't absorb heat that easily). If something is stupid, but works, it ain't stupid ðŸ˜‰
data.author: Artur Bowsza

data.text: Thank you very ! That's a great idea! It's not stupid, it's science actually!
data.author: Evangelos Silva Angelopoulos
